Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s 1968 Night of the Living Dead spawned the full-feature zombie craze in the 1970s, including popular theatrical classics such as The Living Dead at the Manchester Morgue, Zombie, Dawn of the Dead and The Return of the Living Dead.

The US — a land where anyone from anywhere can pick up their spatula for debate and comment publicly on any topic of their liking — and The Dutch — a tightly knit society where one must be related by blood, word or deed before being qualified to develop a concurred opinion without first having gone through a rigorous vaccination program of insult

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Universal’s Technicolor. The supporting performances are outstanding, but the lead is pretty dull and unfeasibly handsome. The film is a little long, but there’s more than enough action and drama to keep most of the audience happy.
